title: Use Managers to Save and Read Data
While you can use the
NSUserDefaults
c
methods anywhere, it can sometimes be better to define a manager that saves and reads from
NSUserDefaults
c
for you and then use that manager for reading or writing your data.

inline_content.Text: methods anywhere, it can sometimes be better to define a manager that saves and reads from
for you and then use that manager for reading or writing your data.

title: Suppose that we want to save a user’s score into
NSUserDefaults
c
. We can create a class like the one below that has at two methods:
setHighScore
c
and
highScore
c
. Anywhere you want to access the high scores, create an instance of this class.

title: The implementation of your read and write process is only in one place and you can change it (for example switch from
NSUserDefaults
c
to Core Data) whenever you want and not worry about changing all places that you are working with the high score.

title: Simply call only one method when you want to access to score or write it.

title: If you are worried about synchronization, it is better to use a singleton class that manages the synchronization.
